THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Ex Parte:  South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services,       
Appellant,
In re:Â  State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company,       
Plaintiff,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Justin Jackson, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years; Paul M. Jackson, III, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years; Tesa K. Jackson, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years; Joseph Rakes, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years; and Nikkia Rakes, a minor under the age of fourteen (14) years,       
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal from Anderson County
Joseph J. Watson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25852
Heard June 24, 2003 - Filed August 9, 2004
Reheard January 20, 2005 - Refiled June 6, 2005

AFFIRMED IN RESULT


  
    
      
George R. Burnett, South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Patricia Logan Harrison, of Columbia, for Respondents.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This case was certified for review pursuant to SCACR 204(b).Â  After hearing oral arguments, this Court issued an opinion affirming the trial judgeâ€™s decision to distribute insurance proceeds into Special Needs Trusts for the injured children and to grant the South Carolina Department of Health and Human Services (â€œMedicaidâ€) a right to the proceeds upon the childrenâ€™s death.Â  Ex Parte: South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health and Human Services, Op. No. 25529 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 9, 2004) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 31 at 42).Â  We subsequently granted Medicaidâ€™s petition for rehearing, and following rehearing, we withdraw our prior opinion and substitute it with this opinion.Â  For a different reason than in our prior opinion, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s decision. 
Factual / Procedural background
Five fourteen-year-olds were injured in a single-car automobile accident in 1999.Â  The children were treated for their injuries, which were minor for Paul Jackson, Joseph Rakes, and Tesa Jackson and extensive for Justin Jackson (Justin) and Nikkia Rakes (Nikkia).[1]Â  Medicaid paid $92,494.18 of approximately $183,000 in medical costs for Justin, and it paid $28,911.71 of approximately $105,000 in costs for Nikkia.Â  
State Farm Insurance Company (Insurer) filed an interpleader action, asking the court to â€œallocate the allegedly available insurance proceedsâ€ among the five children.[2]Â  In total, the driverâ€™s policy consisted of a $50,000 liability policy and two $50,000 underinsured motorist policies.Â  At the hearing, Medicaid appeared and argued that it was to be reimbursed before the proceeds could be paid to the children.
The trial judge ruled that the proceeds from the underinsured policies were not subject to subrogation and assignment, and therefore, Medicaid only had a claim to the $50,000 in proceeds stemming from the liability policy.Â  The judge then distributed the available funds among the five children, placing the proceeds for Nikkia and Justin into Special Needs Trusts[3] for their benefit during their lifetime.Â  In addition, the judge noted that Medicaid would be permitted, upon the childrenâ€™s deaths, to recover any proceeds remaining in the trusts.Â  Finally, the trial judge awarded Medicaid $6,000, representing one-third of the liability insurance proceeds given to the other three children.[4]Â Â Â  
Medicaid appealed and raised the following issue for review:Â  

Did the trial judge err in placing the insurance proceeds into Special Needs Trusts before satisfying Medicaidâ€™s claim to those proceeds?Â Â  

Law/Analysis
Medicaid argues that the trial judge erred in placing the insurance proceeds into Special Needs Trusts before satisfying Medicaidâ€™s claim to those proceeds.Â  We disagree.Â  Because Medicaid was unable to establish that it had obtained an enforceable assignment of rights, Medicaid was not immediately entitled to the proceeds.Â Â Â  
In order to receive Medicaid benefits, an individual must â€œassign the State any rights, of the individual or of any other person who is eligible for medical assistance â€¦ and on whose behalf the individual has the legal authority to execute an assignment of such rights, to support . . . and to payment for medical care from any third party.â€Â  42 U.S.C. Â§ 1396k(a)(1)(A) (2000).Â  Under South Carolina statutory law, such an assignment of rights is automatic.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 43-7-420(A) (Supp. 2002) (providing that â€œ[e]very applicant or recipient, only to the extent of the amount of medical assistance paid by Medicaid, shall be deemed to have assigned his rights to recoverâ€) (emphasis added).Â  Federal law, however, provides the following safeguard: â€œ[i]f assignment of rights to benefits is automatic because of State law, the [state agency] may substitute such an assignment for an individual executed assignment, as long as the [state agency] informs the individual of the terms and consequences of the State law.â€Â  42 C.F.R. Â§ 433.146(c) (emphasis added).
In the present case, Medicaid admitted that it did not have a written assignment of rights.[5]Â  In addition, there is no evidence in the record that Medicaid informed the recipients of the consequences of receiving treatment covered by Medicaid.Â Â  In fact, at the rehearing before this Court, counsel for Medicaid confirmed that there was no evidence that a written assignment had been made or that the recipients had otherwise been informed of the law.Â  Due to the lack of evidence that a valid assignment, whether actual or constructive, was obtained, we hold that Medicaid did not have an immediate right to the proceeds.Â  Therefore, the trial judgeâ€™s decision to place the proceeds in the trusts before reimbursing Medicaid was proper.Â  
Under the terms of a Special Needs Trust, however, Medicaid is entitled to receive any funds remaining in the trusts upon the death of Justin and Nikkia. See 42 U.S.C. Â§ 1396(p)(d)(4)(A) (2000) (providing that â€œthe State will receive all amounts remaining in the trust upon the death of [an individual under age 65 who is disabled] up to an amount equal to the total medical assistance paid on behalf of the individual under [Medicaid]â€).Â  Therefore, the trial judge properly found that Medicaid had a right to the proceeds remaining in the trusts upon the childrenâ€™s death.Â  
Conclusion
Based on the absence of an enforceable assignment of rights, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s decision to place the insurance proceeds into Special Needs Trusts before reimbursing Medicaid.Â  Medicaid is, however, entitled to receive any funds remaining in the trusts upon the childrenâ€™s death.Â  Therefore, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s decision in result.
MOORE and WALLER, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which BURNETT, J., concurs.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  As I understand Medicaid, a prerequisite to enrollment in the program is the assignment of third party medical benefits.Â  In the case of minors such as Justin and Nikkia, the assignment is to be made by the individual with the legal authority to execute such an assignment on the minorâ€™s behalf.Â  I can find no statutory requirement that the assignment be written, as the majority suggests is necessary.Â  Further, given that the assignment issue was not litigated below, it is not surprising that the record contains no evidence concerning compliance. I therefore respectfully dissent from the majorityâ€™s decision to affirm at this juncture, and would remand to allow this issue to be explored.
BURNETT, J., concurs.

[1] Justin suffered a closed-head injury, which resulted in major brain damage.Â  He is confined to a wheelchair.Â  Nikkia suffered a spinal injury and will never walk again.
[2] Although Insurer offered to pay the proceeds, Insurer specifically denied liability throughout the complaint.Â  
[3] A Special Needs Trust is a type of trust permitted under federal law pursuant to 42 U.S.C. 1396p(d)(4)(A) (2000).
[4] No issue was raised regarding the proceeds given to the other three children.
[5] We do not, as the dissent suggests, hold that an assignment of rights must be in writing.Â  We merely note that there is no evidence in the record that Medicaid obtained a written assignment.Â  At oral argument before this Court, counsel for Medicaid stated that it was Medicaidâ€™s practice to obtain assignments of rights in writing, which in our view makes sense, particularly in cases such as this one, where the recipients are minors.

title: Wooten v. Wooten
description: The Supreme Court granted both parties' certiorari petitions to consider two Court of Appeals' decisions in this divorce matter.  The Supreme Court held that the Court of Appeals erred in reversing the award of the marital home to Respondent/Petitioner (Wife) in equitable distribution of the marital estate, and discussed the distinction between awarding the home as an incident of support and in equitable distribution.  The Supreme Court affirmed the Court of Appeals' conclusion that Wife's credit card debt incurred after marital litigation began was not a marital debt subject to apportionment.  The Supreme Court affirmed the Court of Appeals's conclusion that Petitioner/Respondent (Husband) was not required to secure an alimony award with a life insurance policy naming Wife as the beneficiary, and further clarified the standards and analysis used to decide this issue.  The Supreme Court affirmed the Court of Appeals' decision requiring Husband to pay Wife's attorney's fees.

ORDER

 Respondent/Petitioner (Wife) filed a petition for rehearing in which she asked the Court to clarify whether it intended to reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ remand of the issue of the alimony award to the family court.Â  Petitioner/Respondent (Husband) filed a return in opposition.

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Judy C. Bridges, Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 25977
Heard March 2, 2005 - Filed May 2, 2005
Refiled June 6, 2005Â Â 

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Robert N. Rosen of Rosen Law Firm, LLC, of Charleston, and Donald B. Clark, of Charleston, for Mona Rae Wooten (Respondent/Petitioner and Petitioner).
James T. McLaren and C. Dixon Lee, III, both of McLaren & Lee, of Columbia; and Lon H. Shull, III, of Andrews & Shull, PC, of Mt. Pleasant, for Thomas Durrette Wooten, Jr. (Petitioner/Respondent and Respondent).
      
    
  


 JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  This divorce case raises issues related to equitable distribution and alimony.Â  We granted both partiesâ€™ petitions for a writ of certiorari in one appeal and a certiorari petition in the second appeal to review issues addressed in two opinions issued by the Court of Appeals.Â  Wooten v. Wooten, 356 S.C. 473, 589 S.E.2d 769 (Ct. App. 2003); Wooten v. Wooten, 358 S.C. 54, 594 S.E.2d 854 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  We consolidate the two appeals for review and resolution.Â  See Rule 214, SCACR.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTUAL AND PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Thomas D. Wooten, Jr. (Husband) and Mona Rae Wooten (Wife) were married in 1976.Â  The couple met in Columbia while Husband was in medical residency training and moved to Johns Island in 1981, where they lived until Husband moved out of the marital home in 1999.Â  Both parties had adulterous affairs in the mid-1980s, but admitted the affairs to each other, attended counseling sessions, and reconciled.Â  Wife testified Husbandâ€™s decision to leave surprised her and she believed their marriage, while not perfect, was solid.Â Â  
Husband, now age 56, is an anesthesiologist with a gross annual income of $217,000.Â  Wife, a registered nurse by training, is a county deputy coroner with a gross annual income of $47,000.Â  After moving to Johns Island, Wife stayed home for several years to care for the coupleâ€™s three young children.Â  The children were emancipated at the time of trial.Â  Wife also managed the billing of Husbandâ€™s patients to increase the familyâ€™s income.Â  Wifeâ€™s business duties ended in 1987 when Husband hired a secretary to do the billing and then later merged his practice with other anesthesiologists.
The couple and their children lived an affluent lifestyle.Â  They extensively renovated and expanded their home in the early 1980s and often entertained family and friends on weekends at the home and on their boat.Â  Husband frequently went fishing and hunting.Â  They belonged to a country club and regularly went out to dinner.Â  Husband bought and sold several boats during the marriage, including at least one capable of deep-sea fishing trips, and kept two boats valued at $30,000 as part of his division of the coupleâ€™s personal property.Â  
Husband began a adulterous relationship before marital litigation commenced.Â  Husband admitted his misconduct and has not appealed the family courtâ€™s grant of a divorce to Wife on the ground of adultery.
The parties agreed on an equal division of the $1.3 million marital estate, which consisted primarily of the $675,000 marital home, which was subject to mortgages totaling $230,625; Husbandâ€™s retirement and pension accounts of $844,026; the $41,000 valuation of Husbandâ€™s interest in his medical practice; and Wifeâ€™s retirement account of $11,077.
The family court, essentially adopting a proposal offered by Wifeâ€™s accountant, divided the marital assets equally by awarding the marital home to Wife and the bulk of Husbandâ€™s retirement accounts to him.Â  Husband also was ordered to pay Wife $4,300 per month in alimony, with Wife receiving $2,867 per month after taxes.Â  The family court denied Wifeâ€™s request Husband secure the alimony award by maintaining a life insurance policy naming her as beneficiary.Â  The family court ordered Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees of $52,917.
ISSUES

I.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in reversing the family courtâ€™s decision to award the marital home to Wife in equitably distributing the marital estate?Â  
II.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in reversing the family courtâ€™s decision to award a credit card debt, incurred by Wife after marital litigation began, to Husband in equitably distributing the marital estate?Â  
III.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the family courtâ€™s decision not to require Husband to secure an alimony award to Wife with a life insurance policy naming Wife as beneficiary?Â  
IV.Â  Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the family courtâ€™s decision to require Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees and costs, where the Court of Appeals reversed the family courtâ€™s decision in favor of Wife on the primary issues in dispute?Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, an appellate court has the authority to find the facts in accordance with its own view of the preponderance of the evidence.Â  Rutherford v. Rutherford, 307 S.C. 199, 414 S.E.2d 157 (1992); Owens v. Owens, 320 S.C. 543, 466 S.E.2d 373 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  This broad scope of review does not, however, require the appellate court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Stevenson v. Stevenson, 276 S.C. 475, 279 S.E.2d 616 (1981).Â  Neither is the appellate court required to ignore the fact that the family court, who saw and heard the witnesses, was in a better position to evaluate their credibility and assign comparative weight to their testimony.Â  Cherry v. Thomasson, 276 S.C. 524, 280 S.E.2d 541 (1981).
LAW AND ANALYSIS
I.Â  MARITAL HOME 
Testimony during the five-day trial focused primarily on the equitable division of the two major marital assets - the marital home and the retirement accounts.Â  Husband sought to have the assets divided equally by awarding half the retirement accounts to each, selling the house to take full advantage of the $500,000 capital gains tax exclusion for married spouses, and dividing the sale proceeds so that each party could purchase a smaller house with no mortgage.
Husband and his accountant testified that, if Wife were awarded the home, Husband would suffer tax and withdrawal penalties equaling fifty-one percent of any funds he withdrew if required to liquidate his retirement accounts to satisfy the equitable division award and make a substantial down-payment on a home for himself.Â  Wife sought to keep the house as part of her division of the marital estate.Â  
The family court divided the primary marital property and debts in a manner which gave each party a net total of $664,078.Â  Husband received assets of $590,087 in IRA retirement funds, $116,543 in his medical practiceâ€™s retirement pension, the $41,000 value of his medical practice, and debt of $71,230 (representing 75 percent of the home equity line) and a credit card debt of $12,322.Â  Wife received assets of the $675,000 marital home, $137,395 from Husbandâ€™s IRA account, her retirement fund of $11,077, and debts of $135,651 for the first mortgage on the marital home and $23,743 (representing 25 percent of the home equity line).[1]
The family court did not consider Husbandâ€™s fault in awarding the home to Wife, but primarily considered the length of the marriage, Wifeâ€™s needs, the partiesâ€™ lifestyle during the marriage, and Husbandâ€™s ability to pay.Â  The family court did not award the home as an incident of support, but as an asset to be equitably divided, and did not consider the custody or interests of the children because they were emancipated.Â  Further, the family court did not consider speculative tax ramifications related to either the potential sale of the home by Wife or potential early withdrawals from retirement accounts by Husband.
A divided Court of Appeals reversed, with the majority finding the family court abused its discretion by performing an inequitable â€œin-kindâ€ distribution of dissimilar assets and by failing to consider the tax consequences of Husbandâ€™s necessary liquidation of his retirement accounts.Â Â Â  Wooten, 358 S.C. at 60-64, 594 S.E.2d at 858-60.
Wife argues the Court of Appealsâ€™ majority erred in reversing the family courtâ€™s decision to award the marital home to her in equitably distributing the marital estate by incorrectly applying the standards for awarding a house as an incident of support.Â  Furthermore, the Court of Appeals erred in concluding the division was inequitable or likely to result in tax consequences by forcing Husband to liquidate his retirement accounts to comply with the order.Â  Husband contends the family court erred in failing to consider the tax consequences of its order.Â Â Â  
The apportionment of marital property is within the discretion of the family court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Morris v. Morris, 295 S.C. 37, 39, 367 S.E.2d 24, 24 (1988).Â  In order to effect an equitable apportionment, the family court may require the sale of marital property and a division of the proceeds.Â  Donahue v. Donahue, 299 S.C. 353, 360, 384 S.E.2d 741, 745 (1989).Â  However, the court should first try to make an â€œin-kindâ€ distribution of the marital assets, i.e., award a share of each type of asset to each spouse.Â  Id.Â  
The family court may grant a spouse title to the marital home as part of the equitable distribution because it is not feasible to make an in-kind distribution of the home.Â  Donahue, 299 S.C. at 360, 384 S.E.2d at 745; Brown v. Brown, 279 S.C. 116, 302 S.E.2d 860 (1983) (upholding family courtâ€™s decision to award marital home to wife as part of equitable distribution of marital property), overruled on other grounds by Tiffault v. Tiffault, 303 S.C. 391, 401 S.E.2d 157 (1991); Josey v. Josey, 291 S.C. 26, 32, 351 S.E.2d 891, 895 (Ct. App. 1986) (reversing family courtâ€™s decision not to award marital home to wife as part of equitable distribution because family court believed she could not afford it, where wife â€œlove[d] the home dearly,â€ husband did not object to award of house to wife so long as it did not result in increased alimony, and such a disposition under then-existing tax laws would minimize possibility of husband paying capital gains taxes).Â  
The family court should give appropriate weight to the fifteen statutory factors in making an equitable distribution of marital property.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (Supp. 2004).Â  Such factors include the income and earning potential of each spouse, the opportunity for future acquisition of capital assets, the physical and emotional health of each spouse, and the desirability to award the family home as part of the equitable distribution.Â  Section 20-7-472(4), (5) and (10).
The family court is required to consider the tax consequences to each party resulting from equitable apportionment.Â  Section 20-7-472(11).Â  However, if the apportionment order does not contemplate the liquidation or sale of an asset, then it is an abuse of discretion for the court to consider the tax consequences from a speculative sale or liquidation.Â  Bowers v. Bowers, 349 S.C. 85, 97-98, 561 S.E.2d 610, 617 (Ct. App. 2002); Ellerbe v. Ellerbe, 323 S.C. 283, 289, 473 S.E.2d 881, 884 (Ct. App. 1996); Graham v. Graham, 301 S.C. 128, 131, 390 S.E.2d 469, 471 (Ct. App. 1990).
Husband relies in part on law relating to the award of exclusive use and possession of the marital home for a defined term as an incident of support.Â  E.g., Whitfield v. Hanks, 278 S.C. 165, 293 S.E.2d 314 (1982) (discussing possession of residence for specified period as incident of support); Harlan v. Harlan, 300 S.C. 537, 541-42, 389 S.E.2d 165, 168 (Ct. App. 1990) (explaining family court, when awarding marital home for reasonable period as incident of support, must balance competing interests between claim of dependent spouse or children against claim of nonoccupying spouse for his share of marital home; court should consider factors such as need for adequate shelter for minors, suitable housing for handicapped or infirm spouse, and inability of occupying spouse to otherwise obtain adequate housing); Johnson v. Johnson, 285 S.C. 308, 311, 329 S.E.2d 443, 445 (Ct. App. 1985) (same); see also S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472(10) (Supp. 2004). 
The incident-of-support cases are largely irrelevant in deciding whether the marital home should be awarded to one spouse in the equitable division of marital property.Â  A decision on whether to award the marital home to one spouse for a defined period as an incident of support and a decision on whether to award the home permanently to one spouse in equitable distribution require different analyses.Â  While it is proper for the family court to consider support-related facts in both settings, the lack of a support-related rationale should not necessarily prevent or reduce the likelihood of an award of the marital home to one spouse in equitable distribution. 
Instead, as we have done in deciding these appeals, the family court should focus on a fair distribution of the entire marital estate.Â  The family court should consider not only financial factors (including tax consequences, if any) affecting the distribution of the marital home, but also the physical and emotional well-being of each spouse as it relates to the marital home.Â  In other words, decisions relating to the equitable distribution of the marital home should not always be based solely or primarily on a cold, rational calculation of dollars and cents.Â  The family court is free to consider other, less tangible factors asserted by a spouse, weighing those in concert with the financial impact on the parties.
Applying the above principles, we reverse the Court of Appeals and affirm the family courtâ€™s award of the marital home to Wife for four reasons.
First, the Court of Appealsâ€™ majority erred in concluding the family court was required to consider the tax consequences to Husband.Â  The order neither contemplates nor requires, either explicitly or implicitly, the sale of the marital home by Wife or the liquidation of retirement funds by Husband.Â  Such a conclusion is reached only by accepting at face value Husbandâ€™s assertions he cannot afford to comply with the order and buy himself a home without liquidating his retirement accounts.Â  
Second, the record shows Husbandâ€™s income and earning potential far exceed Wifeâ€™s; therefore, Husbandâ€™s ability to purchase a home and acquire other capital assets in the future is also greater than Wifeâ€™s.
Third, Wifeâ€™s emotional attachment to the family home and her wish to keep it in the family in order for future generations to enjoy is a factor to be considered in awarding the home to her, as that likely will benefit her emotional and physical health.Â  In contrast, Husband viewed the disposition of the marital home primarily in financial terms.
Fourth, the record reveals Husbandâ€™s claims of financial ruin are unfounded.Â  Husbandâ€™s gross monthly income exceeds $18,000, with a net spendable income exceeding $12,000 per month.Â  We agree with the family court that, accepting Husbandâ€™s expenses as enumerated in his financial declaration, including the alimony payment, home equity line payment, and a $2,000 mortgage payment to buy his own house, Husbandâ€™s needs can be met from his income.Â  Moreover, Husbandâ€™s earning capacity is more than four times that of Wifeâ€™s, with the potential to be even higher.Â  
We are not persuaded by Husbandâ€™s implication a total debt of $236,469 resulting from the order is immediately due and payable and thus requires liquidation of his retirement funds.Â  The home equity line which was allocated to Husband includes the $30,000 borrowed for attorneyâ€™s fees during litigation.Â  The home equity line does not have to be paid in full immediately and was accounted for by the family court as one of Husbandâ€™s monthly expenses.Â  Whether Husbandâ€™s own attorneyâ€™s fees are immediately payable is unknown.Â  The only debt which is immediately due and payable is $52,917 for Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  
The family court properly effected an equitable division of the marital estate and did not abuse its discretion in awarding the marital home to Wife.Â  Additionally, the Court of Appeals remanded the alimony issue because it was closely related to the award of the marital home and recalculation of various expenses would be necessary if Wife did not remain in the marital home.Â  See Wooten, 358 S.C. at 64, 594 S.E.2d at 860.Â  Given our decision upholding the family courtâ€™s award of the marital home to Wife, further consideration of the amount of alimony award is unnecessary.
II.Â  CREDIT CARD DEBT
Husband vacated the marital home in February 1999.Â  He continued paying the two mortgages and voluntarily gave money to Wife to pay household and child-related expenses until filing an action for separate support and maintenance in June 1999.Â  From June to December 1999, when the pendente lite order required Husband to pay temporary alimony, Husband continued paying the mortgages but did not provide any additional funds to Wife.Â  
Wife incurred a credit card debt of $12,322 from June to December 1999.Â  Wife testified the expenditures were for groceries, dining out, veterinary bills, medications, gasoline, Christmas gifts, and tuition for their son.Â  The record does not contain credit card bills listing the expenses.
The family court treated the credit card debt as marital debt and apportioned it entirely to Husband.Â  The Court of Appeals reversed, holding the credit card debt was not presumed to be a marital debt because it was incurred after the date of commencement of marital litigation.Â  Wife failed to carry her burden of proving the debt was incurred for the benefit of the marriage; therefore, the family court erred in apportioning it as a marital debt.Â  Wooten, 358 S.C. at 59-60, 594 S.E.2d at 857-58. 
â€œMarital propertyâ€ is defined as â€œall real and personal property which has been acquired by the parties during the marriage and which is owned as of the date of filing or commencement of marital litigation. . . .â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-473 (Supp. 2004).Â  For purposes of equitable distribution, a â€œmarital debtâ€ is a debt incurred for the joint benefit of the parties regardless of whether the parties are legally liable or whether one party is individually liable.Â  Hardy v. Hardy, 311 S.C. 433, 436-37, 429 S.E.2d 811, 813 (Ct. App. 1993).
Marital debt, like marital property, must be specifically identified and apportioned in equitable distribution.Â  Smith v. Smith, 327 S.C. 448, 457, 486 S.E.2d 516, 520 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  In equitably dividing the marital estate, the family court must consider â€œliens and any other encumbrances upon the marital property, which themselves must be equitably divided, or upon the separate property of either of the parties, and any other existing debts incurred by the parties or either of them during the course of the marriage.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-472 (13) (Supp. 2004).Â  This statute creates a rebuttable presumption that a debt of either spouse incurred prior to the beginning of marital litigation is a marital debt and must be factored in the totality of equitable apportionment.Â  Hickum v. Hickum, 320 S.C. 97, 102, 463 S.E.2d 321, 324 (Ct. App. 1995); Hardy, 311 S.C. at 436-37, 429 S.E.2d at 813-14.Â  When the debt is incurred before marital litigation begins, the burden of proving a debt is nonmarital rests upon the party who makes such an assertion.Â  Hickum, 320 S.C. at 103, 463 S.E.2d at 324.
When a debt is incurred after the commencement of litigation but before the final divorce decree, the family court may equitably apportion it as a marital debt when it is shown the debt was incurred for marital purposes, i.e., for the joint benefit of both parties during the marriage.Â  Jenkins v. Jenkins, 345 S.C. 88, 104-05, 545 S.E.2d 531, 540 (Ct. App. 2001) (remanding for family court to determine whether payments or debts incurred by husband after filing of litigation were marital debts); Peirson v. Calhoun, 308 S.C. 246, 252-53, 417 S.E.2d 604, 607-08 (Ct. App. 1992) (finding that a second mortgage and other loans obtained by husband post-separation were marital debts).Â  When a debt is incurred after marital litigation begins, the burden of proving the debt is marital rests upon the party who makes such an assertion. 
Wife argues the Court of Appeals erred because it failed to recognize a marital debt may arise after marital litigation is filed.Â  Wife asserts the credit card debt was incurred for the benefit of both parties during the marriage and should be apportioned to Husband.Â  We disagree.
The Court of Appeals correctly concluded Wife incurred the credit card debt after the marital litigation was filed and the record reveals the debt was not incurred for the joint benefit of the parties during the marriage.Â  Wife failed to carry her burden of proving the credit card debt was a marital debt.[2]
III.Â  LIFE INSURANCE TO SECURE AWARD OF ALIMONY
Husband maintained a $1 million life insurance policy during the marriage, paying an annual premium of $2,220.Â  Although the beneficiary named in the policy was a trust, it was maintained for the benefit of Wife and the children.Â  The family court rejected Wifeâ€™s request Husband be ordered to maintain the policy, with Wife as the beneficiary, as security for Wifeâ€™s alimony award.Â  The family court found no â€œcompelling reasonâ€ for such a requirement, reasoning Wife was employed in a relatively secure employment with a substantial income and benefits, there were no minor children, and neither Husband nor Wife suffered from any major or debilitating health problems. 
The Court of Appeals affirmed, citing its own precedent and holding the family court correctly ruled that a â€œcompelling reasonâ€ must exist to warrant the maintenance of life insurance by the payor spouse to secure an alimony award.Â  The Court of Appeals explained it has required a showing of special circumstances or a compelling reason before requiring the purchase or maintenance of life insurance as security for alimony or child support obligations.Â  Neither the alimony nor child support statutes set forth the requirement of special circumstances or compelling reason, but the Court of Appeals, adhering to its precedent, found the requirement exists in both statutes.Â  Wooten, 356 S.C. at 476-77, 589 S.E.2d at 770-71.Â  The Court of Appeals examined the record in light of the statutory factors and upheld the family courtâ€™s denial of Wifeâ€™s request for life insurance to secure the alimony award.Â  Id. at 478, 589 S.E.2d at 771-72.Â Â  
Wife, relying primarily on Gilfillin v. Gilfillin, 344 S.C. 407, 544 S.E.2d 829 (2001), argues the Court of Appeals erred by grafting the â€œcompelling reasonâ€ requirement onto a statute which simply requires an analysis and balancing of statutory factors in deciding whether to secure an alimony award with life insurance.Â  Wife further contends the Court of Appeals erred in upholding the family courtâ€™s ruling after examining the record in light of the statutory factors. 
It is a settled proposition of law that a former wife who is entitled to alimony has an insurable interest in her former husbandâ€™s life.Â  Shealy v. Shealy, 280 S.C. 494, 497, 313 S.E.2d 48, 50 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  The parties in a divorce proceeding may agree, in a private agreement subsequently merged into the courtâ€™s order, that a payor spouse shall maintain life insurance to secure an award of alimony or child support.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 93, 320 S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984); Carnie v. Carnie, 252 S.C. 471, 473, 167 S.E.2d 297, 298 (1969); Lane v. Williamson, 307 S.C. 230, 414 S.E.2d 177 (Ct. App. 1992).
At common law, the obligation to pay periodic alimony ended at death unless a spouse binds his or her estate for the payment of alimony by agreement.Â  McCune v. McCune, 284 S.C. 452, 455, 327 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985).Â  This Court first approved the use of life insurance as security for a support award in Fender v. Fender, 256 S.C. 399, 182 S.E.2d 755 (1971).Â  In that case, we affirmed a divorce decree requiring the husband to maintain a life insurance policy to assure funds would be available for the college education of his minor child.Â  We relied on the grant of broad powers contained in the child support statute,[3] finding the only limits are that court-ordered â€œprovisions shall be just and equitable, considered in light of the circumstances of the parties, the nature of the case, and the best interests of the children.â€Â  Fender, 256 S.C. at 409, 182 S.E.2d at 759; see also Jackson v. Jackson, 264 S.C. 599, 602-03, 216 S.E.2d 530, 531 (1975) (affirming divorce decree which did not require maintenance of life insurance by husband to secure college education of his children because circumstances showed it was not necessary); Brown v. Brown, 270 S.C. 370, 242 S.E.2d 422 (1978) (affirming divorce decree requiring maintenance of life insurance by husband to secure college education of child).
In 1985, the Court of Appeals, relying on Fender and the child support statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-160 (1985), held the family court has the authority to require a payor spouse to maintain a life insurance policy naming his child as beneficiary, provided the requirement is â€œbased on justice, equity, and compelling reasons for this necessity.â€Â  Ivey v. Ivey, 286 S.C. 315, 318, 334 S.E.2d 123, 125 (Ct. App. 1985) (finding no compelling reason requiring husband to secure child support with life insurance); see also Sutton v. Sutton, 291 S.C. 401, 353 S.E.2d 884 (Ct. App. 1987) (affirming divorce decree requiring husband to maintain life insurance to secure child support).
In Hardin v. Hardin, 294 S.C. 402, 365 S.E.2d 34 (Ct. App. 1987), the Court of Appeals in a case of first impression concluded the family court required either specific statutory authority or a finding of special circumstances before it could require a payor spouse to purchase life insurance to secure the payment of periodic alimony beyond the payor spouseâ€™s death.Â  The family court lacked either form of authority in this instance and, thus, erred in requiring husband to purchase a policy.Â  Id. at 404, 365 S.E.2d at 35-36.
The Court of Appeals in subsequent cases imposed the requirement of a showing of special circumstances or a compelling reason before a payor spouse could be ordered to secure the payment of alimony or child support with a life insurance policy.Â  Such special circumstances or compelling reasons include major health problems of the payor spouse.Â  Hickman v. Hickman, 294 S.C. 486, 488, 366 S.E.2d 21, 23 (Ct. App. 1988) (finding no special circumstances requiring husband to secure periodic alimony award with life insurance); Shambley v. Shambley, 296 S.C. 405, 408, 373 S.E.2d 689, 690 (Ct. App. 1988) (finding no compelling reason requiring husband to secure childâ€™s future support and education expenses with life insurance); Ferguson v. Ferguson, 300 S.C. 1, 5, 386 S.E.2d 267, 269 (Ct. App. 1989) (finding no special circumstances requiring husband to secure periodic alimony award with life insurance); Harlan v. Harlan, 300 S.C. 537, 540, 389 S.E.2d 165, 167 (Ct. App. 1990) (finding no compelling reason requiring husband to secure child support with life insurance).
In 1990, the Legislature amended S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130 (Supp. 2004) to codify the common law rule that periodic alimony terminates at death, but provided an exception to this rule when alimony is secured pursuant to subsection 20-3-130(D).Â  Gilfillin, 344 S.C. at 412, 544 S.E.2d at 831.
Section 20-3-130 now provides, in pertinent part:

(B)Â  Alimony and separate maintenance and support awards may be granted pendente lite and permanently in such amounts and for periods of time subject to conditions as the court considers just including, but not limited to:
  
(1)Â  Periodic alimony to be paid but terminating on the remarriage or continued cohabitation of the supported spouse or upon the death of either spouse (except as secured in subsection (D)) and terminable and modifiable based upon changed circumstances occurring in the future. . . . 
  
(D)Â  In making an award of alimony or separate maintenance and support, the court may make provision for security for the payment of the support including, but not limited to, requiring the posting of money, property, and bonds and may require a spouse, with due consideration of the cost of premiums, insurance plans carried by the parties during marriage, insurability of the payor spouse, the probable economic condition of the supported spouse upon the death of the payor spouse, and any other factors the court may deem relevant, to carry and maintain life insurance so as to assure support of a spouse beyond the death of the payor spouse.

In Gilfillin, we stated subsection (D) must be strictly construed because it is in derogation of the common law rule that periodic alimony terminates at the death of the payor spouse.Â  We held that life insurance is the only permitted means of securing alimony beyond the life of the payor spouse and struck down the family courtâ€™s creation of an alimony trust.Â  We stated that â€œ[w]ith the enactment of subsection 20-3-130(D), the Legislature provided that life insurance could be used to secure such payment whenever the family court made factual findings concerning the five factors favored requiring such insurance.â€Â  Gilfillin, 344 S.C. at 414, 544 S.E.2d at 832.Â  Further, the â€œuse of life insurance is restricted in subsection (D) for use only after the family court makes comprehensive review of five distinct issues. . . .â€Â  Id.Â  We noted several of the pre-1990 Court of Appealsâ€™ cases listed above which require a finding of â€œspecial circumstances,â€ but did not explicitly endorse or reject such a requirement.[4]
Since 1990, the Court of Appeals has continued to require a showing of â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ or a â€œcompelling reasonâ€ before the family court may order the purchase or maintenance of life insurance as security for an alimony or child support obligation.Â  Wooten, 356 S.C. at 477, 589 S.E.2d at 771 (â€œprecedent of this court, both before and after 1990, has consistently applied the â€˜compelling reasonâ€™ standard to secure the payment of alimony and child supportâ€); Mallett v. Mallett, 323 S.C. 141, 150, 473 S.E.2d 804, 810 (Ct. App. 1996) (finding no compelling reason requiring husband to secure child support award with life insurance); McElveen v. McElveen, 332 S.C. 583, 603-04, 506 S.E.2d 1, 11-12 (Ct. App. 1998) (finding no compelling reason requiring husband to secure child support and alimony payments with life insurance); Allen v. Allen, 347 S.C. 177, 186-87, 554 S.E.2d 421, 426 (Ct. App. 2001) (remanding for family court to reconsider decision requiring husband to secure alimony award with life insurance by making a comprehensive review of statutory factors, and mentioning precedent requiring a showing of special circumstances for such security); Roberson v. Roberson, 359 S.C. 384, 391-92, 597 S.E.2d 840, 844 (Ct. App. 2004) (upholding ruling which required husband to secure alimony award with life insurance where record revealed family court properly considered statutory factors; Court of Appeals cited Wooten, 356 S.C. 473, 589 S.E.2d 769, which requires showing of special circumstances or compelling reason).Â  See also John J. Michalik, Divorce:Â  Provision in Decree That One Party Obtain or Maintain Life Insurance for Benefit of Other Party or Child, 59 A.L.R.3d 9 (1974).
We conclude, in clarifying Gilfillin, the family court must conduct a comprehensive review of the statutory factors to determine whether special circumstances exist which require the purchase or maintenance of a life insurance policy to secure an alimony award.Â  Although the term â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ is not found in the statute, the Legislature was aware of prior case law on this issue when it enacted subsection 20-3-130(D), which indicates the Legislature anticipated the provision would be applied in light of existing precedent.Â  See State v. Bridgers, 329 S.C. 11, 14, 495 S.E.2d 196, 197 (1997) (Legislature is presumed to be aware of common law when enacting statutes and using terms that have a well-recognized meaning in the law); Berkebile v. Outen, 311 S.C. 50, 53, 426 S.E.2d 760, 762 (1993) (basic presumption exists that the Legislature has knowledge of previous legislation when later statutes are passed on a related subject).Â  
However, we disapprove of the requirement of a showing of a â€œcompelling reasonâ€ before life insurance may be ordered to secure an alimony award.Â  While the difference between â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ and a â€œcompelling reasonâ€ may appear semantic, use of the latter term arguably places a higher burden on the spouse requesting security.Â  We also reject the conclusion a â€œcourt-mandated requirement for life insurance to secure the alimony payments is the exception, not the rule.â€Â  Wooten, 356 S.C. at 478, 589 S.E.2d at 772.
The Court of Appealsâ€™ requirement of a â€œcompelling reason,â€ combined with its view that court-mandated life insurance is the exception, not the rule, effectively established a presumption against ordering life insurance to secure an alimony award.Â  The Legislature did not intend to establish a presumption in favor of or against such security under the statute.Â  Instead, as we indicated in Gilfillin, the statute contemplates a comprehensive review of the factors set out in subsection 20-3-130(D).Â  If that review reveals the existence of special circumstances in which the supported spouse establishes the need for the security and the payor spouse is capable of providing it, the family court may order the award be secured with life insurance.
In making such a determination, the analysis should begin with the supported spouseâ€™s need for such security, i.e., consideration of the supported spouseâ€™s probable economic condition in the event of the payor spouseâ€™s death.Â  The family court should consider the supported spouseâ€™s age, health, income earning ability, and accumulated assets.Â  If a need for security is found, the family court should next consider the payor spouseâ€™s ability to secure the award with life insurance, i.e., the payor spouseâ€™s age, health, income earning ability, accumulated assets, insurability, cost of premiums, and insurance plans carried by the parties during the marriage.Â  The cost of premiums could be assigned solely to the payor spouse, solely to the payee spouse, or shared between them.[5]
In the instant case, Wife is in good health, has a stable income and substantial assets with which she may support herself should Husband predecease her and alimony payments cease.Â  Husband can afford the premiums, carried the policy during the marriage, and apparently is in good health and insurable.Â  We do not find the existence of special circumstances giving rise to a need for security in this case.Â  We affirm the family court and Court of Appealsâ€™ application of the statutory factors to find Husband was not required to purchase life insurance to secure Wifeâ€™s alimony award.[6]
IV.Â  WIFEâ€™S ATTORNEYâ€™S FEES
Husband argues he should not be required to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneysâ€™ fees because the Court of Appeals reversed the family courtâ€™s ruling in favor of Wife on the main issues in dispute, the distribution of the marital home and the credit card debt.Â  Our resolution of these appeals largely nullifies Husbandâ€™s argument.Â  We affirm.Â  See Glasscock v. Glasscock, 304 S.C. 158, 403 S.E.2d 313 (1991) (listing factors to consider in awarding attorneyâ€™s fees, including beneficial results obtained).
CONCLUSION
We reverse the Court of Appeals and award the marital home to Wife in the equitable division of the marital estate.Â  We affirm the Court of Appeals and conclude Wifeâ€™s credit card debt was not a marital debt.Â  We reverse the Court of Appealsâ€™ requirement the family court find a â€œcompelling reasonâ€ before requiring a spouse to secure an alimony award with life insurance, but affirm the conclusion Husband is not required to secure Wifeâ€™s alimony award with life insurance.Â  We affirm the Court of Appeals and require Husband to pay Wifeâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $52,917.Â  The designation of the credit card debt as nonmarital increases the size of the marital estate by $12,322 and affects the equitable distribution of Husbandâ€™s IRA funds.Â  We remand this case to the family court for reconsideration of that issue in a manner consistent with this opinion.
 AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  Recognizing the potential difficulty of making joint payments, the family court ordered that Wifeâ€™s portion of the home equity line ($23,743) be deducted from Wifeâ€™s portion of the retirement accounts, and Husband would make all payments on that debt.Â  Thus, Wife actually received $113,652 from Husbandâ€™s IRA funds while Husband kept $613,830 in those funds. 
[2]Â  Like the Court of Appeals, we express no opinion on whether the family court could have required Husband to reimburse Wife for some or all of these charges as an incident of support.Â  Wooten, 358 S.C. at 60 n.2, 594 S.E.2d at 858 n.2. 
[3]Â  The language of the present child support statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-160 (1985), is identical to Â§ 20-115 of the 1962 Code interpreted in Fender.
[4]Â  Justice Moore, dissenting, appeared to endorse the requirement of â€œspecial circumstancesâ€ to secure an alimony award.Â  See Gilfillin, 344 S.C. at 416 n.1, 544 S.E.2d at 833 n.1 (Hardin and cases following it â€œdo not prohibit ordering life insurance to secure alimony if there are special circumstances or statutory authorityâ€).
[5]Â  Alimony payments terminate â€œon the remarriage or continued cohabitation of the supported spouse or upon the death of either spouseâ€ and are â€œterminable and modifiable based upon changed circumstances occurring in the future.â€Â  Section 20-3-130(B)(1).Â  A requirement that an alimony award be secured with life insurance is similarly terminable and modifiable.
[6]Â  Some of the cited Court of Appealsâ€™ opinions addressed the issue of securing a child support obligation with life insurance.Â  Our decision today addresses only the securing of an alimony award with life insurance as provided by statute.Â  We express no opinion on the analysis established by the Court of Appeals in the securing of a child support award.

PUBLIC REPRIMAND

Theo W. Mitchell, of Greenville, pro se.
      
    
  


 PER CURIAM:Â  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) and respondent have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, in which respondent admits misconduct and agrees to either an admonition or a public reprimand.Â  We accept the agreement and issue a public reprimand.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Respondent operates a solo practice in Greenville.Â  Respondent employs Anthony Kinsey, a lawyer not licensed to practice law in South Carolina.Â  On June 18, 2004, the Commission on Lawyer Conduct issued a letter of caution to respondent advising him that his reference to Mr. Kinsey as an attorney in communications was misleading.Â  The letter of caution also advised respondent that his use of the firm name â€œTheo Mitchell & Associatesâ€ and his reference to â€œattorneys and counselors at lawâ€ in his communications was misleading if there were no associates or attorneys in his employ.Â  The letter of caution also advised respondent that he should be more careful to adhere to the guidelines set forth in Rules 7.1, 7.5(a), and 7.5(d) of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407,
SCACR.    
After receiving the letter of caution, respondent continued to use the word â€œassociatesâ€ in his firm name and to refer to â€œattorneys and counselors at lawâ€ on his letterhead even though he employed no licensed attorneys other than himself.Â  It was not until receipt of the Notice of Full Investigation in this current matter that respondent discontinued the use of â€œTheo Mitchell & Associates, Attorneys and Counselors at Lawâ€ in his communications.Â  
Respondent now acknowledges that his continued use of the term â€œassociatesâ€ and the phrase â€œattorneys and counselors at lawâ€ could have misled clients about Mr. Kinsey and other staff membersâ€™ status in the law firm.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Â 
LAW
Respondent admits that he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 7.1 (lawyer shall not make false, misleading, deceptive or unfair communications about the lawyer or his services); Rule 7.5(a) (lawyer shall not use a firm name, letterhead, or other professional designation that violates Rule 7.1) and Rule 7.5(d) (lawyer may state or imply he practices in a partnership or other organization only when that is the fact).Â  Respondent acknowledges that his misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be ground for discipline for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).Â  Â Â Â Â 
CONCLUSION
We find that respondentâ€™s misconduct warrants a public reprimand.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and publicly reprimand respondent for his misconduct.
 PUBLIC REPRIMAND.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
JRS Builders, Inc.,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Henry G. Neunsinger, Judy Timms, and Atlantic Savings Bank,
FSB,        Defendants,
Of Whom Henry G. Neunsinger is       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Berkeley County
John B. Williams, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25995
Heard June 10, 2004 - Filed June 6, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Mary Leigh Arnold, of Mt. Pleasant, for appellant.
Steven L. Smith and Wm. Mark Koontz, of Smith, Collins & Newton, P.A., of North Charleston, for respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  After a final judgment in favor of respondent (Builder) in its mechanicâ€™s lien action against petitioner (Homeowner), the master-in-equity awarded attorneyâ€™s fees to Builder as the prevailing party.Â  After certifying this case from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, we affirm in part and reverse in part.
FACTS
On October 30, 1998, Builder brought an action against Homeowner pursuant to the Mechanicâ€™s Lien Statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (1991).Â  Builder asserted he was owed $74,500 for work performed in the construction of a home for Homeowner.Â  Homeowner counterclaimed alleging causes of action for breach of contract, negligent construction, and breach of warranty.Â  Homeownerâ€™s counterclaims sought an unspecified amount in actual and punitive damages.
After hearing the case, the master found Builder was entitled to $65,048 for breach of contract and that Homeowner established he was entitled to $36,907.26 on his counterclaim.Â  The final result was judgment for Builder in the amount of $28,140.76.Â  Attorneyâ€™s fees and costs were not awarded to either party.Â  Homeowner and Builder then filed motions for an award of attorneyâ€™s fees on the ground that each was the prevailing party under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10(b) (providing method for award of attorneyâ€™s fees for prevailing party in action to foreclose mechanicâ€™s lien).[1]
The master filed an amended order.Â  In this order, the award to Homeowner was increased to $44,430.86 and final judgment for Builder was entered in the amount of $20,617.14.Â  Further, the master summarily found the amended version of Â§ 29-5-10, although enacted after the institution of Builderâ€™s action, applied and awarded attorneyâ€™s fees to Builder as the prevailing party.Â  The amount of attorneyâ€™s fees was $29,033.75.
ISSUE

Did the trial court err by finding Builder to be the prevailing party who was entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees pursuant to the amended version of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (Supp. 2003)?

DISCUSSION
Homeowner contends the pre-1999 version of Â§ 29-5-10 should apply when determining who is the prevailing party for the purpose of awarding attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Builder contends the amended version of Â§ 29-5-10 should be applied retroactively.
The prior version of the statute, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (a) (1991), establishes that the prevailing party to an action to foreclose a mechanicâ€™s lien shall be awarded attorneyâ€™s fees and costs up to the amount of the actual lien awarded.Â  Subsection (b) of the statute prescribes the method used for determining who is the prevailing party, and states, in pertinent part:

If the plaintiff makes no written offer of settlement, the amount prayed for in his complaint is considered to be his final offer of settlement for purposes of this section.
If the defendant makes no written offer of settlement, his offer of settlement is considered to be zero.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (b).
In 1997, this Court specifically interpreted the 1991 statute and held the following:

when neither party makes a written offer of settlement, the plaintiffâ€™s offer is considered the amount prayed for in its complaint and the defendantâ€™s offer is considered to be zero.Â  Whether fairly or unfairly, the statute does not make provision for considering counterclaims as negative offers of settlement.Â  

Brasington Tile Co., Inc. v. Worley, 327 S.C. 280, 289, 491 S.E.2d 244, 248 (1997) (emphasis in original).Â  
In response to the Brasington decision, the legislature amended the statute, effective June 11, 1999â€”nearly eight months after the underlying lawsuit was filed.Â  The amended version provides, in pertinent part, the following:Â  

If the defendant makes no written offer of settlement, the value of his counterclaim is considered to be his negative offer of settlement.Â  If the defendant has not asserted a counterclaim, his offer of settlement is considered to be zero.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (b) (Supp. 2003).Â  Application of the amended statute to the facts in Brasington would change the outcome of that case.Â  In other words, if the amended statute were to apply retroactively, the Brasington decision would, in effect, be overruled.Â  
Because the legislature does not have the authority to overrule a decision by this Court, the amended statute cannot apply retrospectively.Â  See Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing and Regulation, 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999) (holding legislature lacked authority to retroactively overrule Courtâ€™s interpretation of a statute).Â  Moreover, we have found that â€œa judicial interpret[ation] of a statute is determinative of its meaning and effect, and any subsequent legislative amendment to the contrary will only be effective from the date of its enactment and cannot be applied retroactively.â€Â  Lindsay v. Natâ€™l Old Line Ins. Co., 262 S.C. 621, 629, 207 S.E.2d 75, 78 (1974).Â  Because a prior, on-point judicial decision has been rendered, any subsequent statutory amendments apply prospectively only.Â  To decide otherwise would allow the legislature, in effect, to overrule judicial decisions in violation of the separation of powers doctrine.[2]
In the present case, the question of who is the prevailing party is controlled by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 (1991) and this Courtâ€™s interpretation of that statute in Brasington.Â  Homeowner is correct in asserting that under the prior version of the statute, he would be the prevailing party.Â  Neither party made a written offer of settlement.Â  Final judgment was entered for Builder in the amount of $20,617.14.Â  Applying the formula in the applicable statute and this Courtâ€™s interpretation of that statute in Brasington, Builderâ€™s settlement offer is the amount prayed for in the complaint, which was $74,500, and Homeownerâ€™s settlement offer is zero.Â  Zero is closer to $20,617.14 than $74,500.Â  Accordingly, Homeowner should have been deemed the prevailing party and the party entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees and costs.
CONCLUSION
We reverse the masterâ€™s decision finding Builder entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as the prevailing party under amended Â§ 29-5-10.Â  Applying the former version of Â§ 29-5-10, we find Homeowner is entitled to attorneyâ€™s fees as the prevailing party in the mechanicâ€™s lien action.Â  Appellantâ€™s second issue is affirmed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authority:Â 
South Carolina Natâ€™l Bank, Greenville v. Hammond, 260 S.C. 622, 198 S.E.2d 123 (1973) (as general rule, it is essential to establishment of set off that claims or debts be mutual, i.e., they must subsist or be owing, between same parties in same right or capacity, and must be of same kind or quality).Â  Therefore, the masterâ€™s decision is 
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion.
JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  In 1974, the Court held that the General Assembly could not, consonant with the separation of powers doctrine, enact a statute in order to overturn the result in a case we had already decided.Â  Lindsay v. Natâ€™l Old Line Ins. Co., 262 S.C. 621, 207 S.E.2d 75 (1974).Â  In other words, the legislature cannot, by legislative enactment, overrule our interpretation of a statute.Â  Boatwright v. McElmurray, 247 S.C. 199, 146 S.E.2d 716 (1966).Â  Over the past several years, Lindsay has been construed as a limitation on the General Assemblyâ€™s authority to amend a statute, and to have that amendment apply retroactively.[3]Â  While I have joined several of these decisions, I have come to believe that this reading of Lindsay, which held only that the General Assembly could not legislatively reverse the Courtâ€™s decision, is overly broad.Â  See Rivers v. Roadway Express, 511 U.S. 298, 114 S.Ct. 1510, 128 L.Ed.2d 274 (1994)(â€œCongress, of course, has the power to amend a statute that it believes we have misconstrued.Â Â  It may even, within broad constitutional bounds, make such a change retroactive and thereby undo what it perceives to be the undesirable past consequences of a misinterpretation of its work productâ€).
Whether a statutory amendment applies retroactively is ordinarily a matter of statutory construction and interpretation, not of constitutional law.Â  The General Assembly has the authority to amend statutes, and to determine whether the amended statute applies to matters occurring before its effective date.Â  The general rule is that â€œstatutory enactments are to be considered prospective rather than retroactive unless there is a specific provision in the enactment or clear legislative intent to the contrary. [citation omitted]. Â However, statutes which are remedial or procedural in nature are generally held to operate retrospectively.â€Â  South Carolina Depâ€™t of Rev. v. Rosemary Coin Machines, Inc., 339 S.C. 25, 528 S.E.2d 416 (2000).Â  The only constitutional limit on retroactivity in a civil context[4] derives from due process guarantees, and from S.C. Const. art. I, Â§ 4, prohibiting the passage of a law that â€œhas the effect of impairing the obligation of contract or divesting vested rights of property.â€ E.g., Schumacher v. Chapin, 228 S.C. 77, 88 S.E.2d 874 (1955).
Through a series of cases citing Lindsay, we have created two different rules regarding statutory retroactivity:Â  If the Court never interpreted the prior statute, then the general rule recited above applies.Â  If, however, the Court has issued an opinion interpreting a statute, any legislative change to that statute is deemed prospective only, lest the legislature invade the province of the Court.Â  In my opinion, this â€œLindsay rule,â€ premised on the separation of powers doctrine, has in fact led to its violation.
The separation of powers doctrine prevents one branch of government from usurping the power and authority of another.Â  Knotts v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Natural Resources, 348 S.C. 1, 558 S.E.2d 511 (2002).Â  It is not the legislatureâ€™s amendment of a statute in response to a judicial interpretation which offends the doctrine, but rather our limitation on the General Assemblyâ€™s authority to decide whether that statutory change should be given retroactive effect. Â As we held in Boatwright, â€œthe legislature has plenary power to amend statutes.â€
In my opinion, we should use this opportunity to abandon our Lindsay retroactivity jurisprudence and return to the general rules of statutory construction.Â  In this case, however, we need not decide whether the amendment to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-10 was procedural or remedial and thus should be given retroactive effect.Â  In 1883, this Court established the rule that entitlement to costs is to be determined by the statute in effect at the time the suit is decided and the costs, if any, are to be awarded.Â  Irwin v. Brooks, 19 S.C. 96 (1883).Â  I would hold that, in the absence of legislative intent to the contrary, entitlement to statutory attorneys fees should be determined pursuant to the statute in effect at the time the final judgment is entered. Id.Â  I would therefore affirm the masterâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees to respondent.
I therefore respectfully dissent.

[1]In 1999, Â§ 29-5-10(b) was amended.Â  As will be discussed infra, Homeowner argues the former statute applies while Builder argues the amended statute applies.
[2]The dissent states the Lindsay analysis should be abandoned because the legislature has plenary power to amend statutes and, as such, this Court should not limit the legislatureâ€™s authority to decide whether a statutory amendment should be given retroactive effect.Â  However, while the legislature has plenary power to amend statutes, the construction of a statute is a judicial function and responsibility.Â  See Lindsay v. Natâ€™l Old Line Ins. Co., 262 S.C. 621, 207 S.E.2d 75 (1974); Boatwright v. McElmurray, 247 S.C. 199, 146 S.E.2d 716 (1966).Â  Therefore, once this Court has construed a particular statute, the legislature cannot thereafter amend the statute to alter our construction of the statute and have the amendment apply retroactively.Â  To do so is to invade upon judicial power.Â Â  
[3] See Simmons v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 355 S.C. 581, 586 S.E.2d 569 (2003); Williamson v. South Carolina Ins. Reserve Fund, 355 S.C. 420, 586 S.E.2d 115 (2003); Dykema v. Carolina Emerg. Physicians, P.C., 348 S.C. 549, 560 S.E.2d 892 (2002); Pike v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Trans., 343 S.C. 224, 540 S.E.2d 87 (2000); Steinke v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, and Reg., 336 S.C. 373, 520 S.E.2d 142 (1999); see also Tilley v. Pacesetter Corp., 355 S.C. 361, 585 S.E.2d 292 (2003).
[4] There are, of course, ex post facto concerns with criminal statutes.
